Award.AwardTitle: Higher-Order Methods for Interface Problems with Non-Aligned Meshes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interface problems arise in several applications including heart models, cochlea models, aquatic animal locomotion, blood cell motion, front-tracking in porous media flows and material science, to name a few. One of the difficulties in these problems is that solutions are normally not smooth across interfaces, and therefore standard numerical methods will lose accuracy near the interface unless the meshes align to it. However, it is advantageous to have meshes that do not align with the interface, especially for time dependent problems where the interface moves with time. Re-meshing at every time step can be prohibitively costly, can destroy the structure of the grid, can deteriorate the well-conditioning of the stiffness matrix, and affect the stability of the problem. The first problem studied will involve new stable and higher-order accurate Finite Element - Immersed Boundary Methods (FE-IBM) for evolution problems where the interface moves with time. The second problem studied is the design and analysis of robust higher-order discretizations for interface problems with high-contrast discontinuous diffusion coefficients. Benefits of the project include the strengthening of connections between numerical analysis and other areas of science and engineering, particularly bioengineering, porous media flows, material sciences and parallel computing. This project will impact the development of numerical algorithms used in the fluid-structure interaction communities. A broader impact will be the training of graduate and undergraduate students of mathematics and related disciplines by exposing them to interdisciplinary problems and collaborations addressing questions of great technological importance.

One of the drawbacks of the finite element and finite difference immersed boundary methods is that they are only first-order accurate due to the non-smoothness of the solution across the interface. Furthermore, very few mathematical analyses of these methods exist for time dependent problems and for fluid-structure interaction problems. The first part of the project involves the construction of higher-order FE-IBM algorithms and establishing a corresponding mathematical foundation to obtain rigorous time stability and a priori and a posteriori error estimates. The second part of the project deals with new finite element methods which are able to accurately capture solutions of elliptic interface problems with high-contrast coefficients in the case that the finite element mesh is not necessarily aligned with the interface. The goal here is to develop finite element methods with optimal convergence rates, where the constants hidden in these estimates are independent of the contrast and on how the mesh crosses the interface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The now summarize  our best outcomes:  

[1] The FETI-DP preconditioner family is maybe the most efficient and scalable class of nonoverlapping domaindecomposition methods to date for a variety of equations. We designed and analyzed  FETI-DP for a DG discretization. This result is breakthrough in the area of preconditioning for any discretization based on DG discretizations. They are now a reference on the domain decomposition field.   

[2] We established optimal $C h$ a priori energy and flux error estimates where the constant $C$ does not depend  on the contrast of the coefficients.

[3]  We  proved  optimal a priori energy and $L^2$ error estimates of a method that modifies classical conforming discretizations into conservative ones.

[4] We  combined  Eikonal discrete techniques and ultra-weak DG discretizations to approximate a nonlinear modified mild-slope equation.

[5,6,7] These are now literature references for the design and analysis of Immersed Interface Methods for Poisson, incompressible Stokes and high-contrast transmission problems.

[8] We introduced a FEM refinement technique for the Beltrami-Laplace equation on surfaces with localized high curvatures.

[9,10] These are the only papers in the literaturethat contain finite element methods with $Ch$-energy error for high-contrastcoefficients without any regularity assumption of the solution and  $C$ does not depend at all on the jumps of the coefficients.

[11] We  introduced a CutFEM for dynamic fluid-membrane interaction which is provable unconditionally stable.

[12]  It lays down the fundamental background theory necessary to design and analyze CutFEM solvers.

References: 

[1] Dryja, Maksymilian and Galvis, Juan and Sarkis, Marcus, {The analysis of a FETI-DP preconditioner for a full DG discretization of elliptic problems in two dimensions}, Numerische Mathematik, 131(4): 737--770, 2015.

[2] Burman, Erik and Guzman, Johnny and Sanchez, Manuel A. and Sarkis, Marcus, {Robust flux error estimation of an unfitted Nitsche method for high-contrast interface problems},  IMA Journal of Numerical Analysis,    32(2): 646--668, 2017.  

[3] Abreu, Eduardo and D\'{i}az, Ciro and Galvis, Juan and Sarkis,              Marcus, {On high-order conservative finite element methods}, Comput. Math. Appl., 75(6):1852--1867, 2018. 

[4] Alvarez, A. C. and Garcia, G. C. and Sarkis, M., {The ultra weak variational formulation for the modified mild-slope equation}, Appl. Math. Model., 52:28--41, 2017. 

[5] Guzman, Johnny and Sanchez, Manuel A. and Sarkis, Marcus, {Higher-order finite element methods for elliptic problems with interfaces},  ESAIM Math. Model. Numer. Anal.},  50(5): 1561--1583, 2016.  

[6] Guzman, Johnny and Sanchez, Manuel A. and Sarkis, Marcus, {On the accuracy of finite element approximations to a class of  interface problems},   Math. Comp.}, 85(301): 2071--2098, 2016.  

[7] Guzman, Johnny and Sanchez, Manuel A. and Sarkis, Marcus, {A finite flement method for high-contrast interface problems with error estimates in dependent  of contrast},  J. Sci. Comput., 73(1): 330--365, 2017.  

[8] Guzman, Johnny and Madureira, Alexandre and Sarkis, Marcus and              Walker, {Analysis of the Finite Element Method for the Laplace--Beltrami Equation on Surfaces with Regions   of High Curvature Using Graded Meshes}, J. Sci. Comput.,  FJOURNAL = 77(3): 1736--1761, 2018. 

[9] Madureira, A. L. and and Sarkis, M.,  {Adaptive ACMS: A robust localized Approximated Component Mode Synthesis Method},  arXiv:1709.04044, 2018.

[10] Madureira, A. L. and and Sarkis, M., {Hybrid Localized Spectral Decomposition for multiscale problems},  arXiv:1706.08941, 2017.

[11] Dunn, D. K.  and Lui, R. and Sarkis,  M., {An unconditionally stable semi-implicit CutFEM for an interaction problem between an elastic membrane and an incompressible fluid}, https://arxiv.org/pdf/1801.05794.pdf}, 2018. 

[12] B. Ayuso de Dios, K. Dunn, M. Sarkis, and S Scacchi, {Dirichlet-Neumann preconditioning for stabilised unfitted discretization of high contrast problems}, submitted DD26 proceedings, 2018. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2018
Modified by: Marcus Sarkis
